The claim made by Jim Sullivan: s campaign literature that Leah Vukmir supports allowing people to carry concealed weapons into day care centers, churches, health care clinics, and playgrounds.
The evidence provided by Sullivan: s campaign, which includes a series of votes by Vukmir in support of Senate Bill 403, a measure that would have allowed individuals to apply for a license to carry concealed weapons.
The analysis of the bill itself: which clarifies that concealed carry would have been allowed in churches and health care clinics only with permission from the owner or authorized representative, in day care centers only for the owner or residents of the home, and in playgrounds and parks without limitations.
The expert: s verdict, which states that the goal is to publish the truth and inform participants in democracy, indicating that the claim has been thoroughly examined and verified.
